title: Can the senses be trusted to distinguish reality from illusion? - Quora

response.answer_text: No one really knows. The best answer is “it depends.” In many cases they can, and in many they can’t. This is an ancient philosophical question that goes right back to Plato’s Cave and beyond. All spiritual practices address this question in one way or another. Love is a good place to start thinking about this seriously. Is love “real”? Can you trust “the senses”? Is there any other way to perceive love? I don’t know. I’ve learned to tell how important love is for me and how easy it is to perceive—and I highly recommend others do as well. Might want to start with Michael Pollan’s very important new book How To Change You’re Mind. Also, see my other answers, I love addressing this question but don’t want to repeat myself. Daniel Quinn’s books such as Ishmael are all excellent answers to this question (and the deepest I know of). Waking up from apparent reality is a very, very tricky business. An Ayahuasca trip or some experimentation with mushrooms can really help clarity one's sense of what is true and really matters. Even microdosing little microchips of schroom can have a deeply clarifying and wisening—not to mention calming—effect. Conversely, approaching things from a pure-science mentality, Chomsky’s Newton talk is the most rigid and rational conception of the limits of knowledge that I know of. It’s a bit tough to get into though, I’ve been studying that talk alone for several years, but it’s been well worth it. And then my Aya trip taught me that, having mastered that kind of thinking, I don’t really find it all that important anymore. Convenient to say though now that I take it for granted. Intuitional/creative knowledge is much more useful than scientific knowledge, especially if one doesn’t mistake it for scientific knowledge (enjoy your beliefs and let them serve you without needing them to be empirically demonstrable to anyone but you and in any other way than that they’re useful. You can say this sentence to any doubters: The essence of empiricism and evolution is that something is apparent and that it works. In those senses my belief in X has been very adaptive for me). You can believe in your beliefs without believing that they’re “scientific.” And you can honestly pity those who are incapable of perceiving anything outside of what little is understood scientifically. At the end of the day understanding via “your senses” is all you have. This is by definition: all you have is your various faculties for making sense of the world. The best answer to the question I can think of is: You have no choice, you’re doing it every day. Even your skepticism is a sense you will never know exactly how much to trust, but trust it you must. Your senses, your reason and your skepticism of them are all you’ve got. Well, that and those of others. Trust of course plays a key role here. Weighing in the perceptions, reasoning, and skepticism of others both historical and contemporary, some lovers and some enemies but most in between, adds so much additional complexity to all of this that I simply have nothing more to say. I hope this leaves you as fascinated by the topic as I am. :)  Ps: Alan Watts may be a bit silly and nonsensical but his work is actually very useful at addressing these questions neither too rigidly nor too loosely.

A2A It is not the senses’ job to distinguish reality from illusion. What sense do is register impulses. The impulses are then passed onto the brain which decides what it is that the senses registered. This is then picked up by the mind which decides the meaning and value and importance and relevance and whatever else, of what’s been registered. The senses register, the brain interprets, the mind evaluates, defines and judges. Some “illusions” happen in the brain. For various reasons the brain can mistakenly translate what’s been registered. For the most part, illusions are created by the mind and are otherwise known as meanings, ideas, beliefs, concepts. For the most part the mind can’t be trusted to recognize the illusions it itself creates. As far as the mind knows, what it creates is what it sees. It’s the reality. It happens sometimes, not often, that the brain is so nimble and developed and that the mind is so present that it can see itself. It can recognize itself and it’s own workings. Or … something can recognize the mind and it’s workings. One can recognize one’s mind and one’s workings. One can become fully aware of one’s mind. In this place of full awareness one can see clearly the illusions mind spins, and one can see clearly the reality behind those illusions. This state of awareness is commonly known as enlightenment.

We humans are easily deceived, hence the graphic and natural illusions that may trick us (rabbit/witch illusion, Escher illusions. Stick in water; seemingly bent) among many others, we often misread scary sounds in the dark, etc. Despite this situation we manage quite well in our everyday lives, occasionally being deceived, but in the main we are aware of our error, or in the case of graphic illusions, we must accept that this is simply how the mind/brain works, how it has evolved to keep us alive in potentially dangerous environments . To maintain constant awareness of potential dangers (predators), we have evolved to be cautious and to take things, initially, at face value; originally it was the difference between life or death. It was better to read things and situations literally, thus on seeing a stick seemingly bent in water, judging it as seeming to be real, till we learn that the very same stick, out of water, is in fact straight. We evolved to diminish risks by assuming that it is better to take care in most situations rather taking a chance. This probably resulted from recognising potential risk situations and avoiding them where possible. Originally, to be careless, just once, meant being a predators dinner. We humans evolved and passed these behaviours on to future generations, today we recognise the result of these evolutionary behaviours as the ‘fight or flight’ reaction. Because we can be rational creatures occasionally, we have learnt and remember that many illusions are just that. But some, like the ‘fight or flight reaction’ are deeply embedded in our psyche and at a visceral level. So while we are prone to making the occasional error due to illusions, in the main, our senses serve us well. Our inherent capacities that have evolved over millions of years, like the ‘blink’ reaction enable us to implicitly avoid most dangerous situations (protecting our eyes), but we can still be, occasionally tricked via our sense. Much of our behaviour is inherent. We are able to act on implicit knowledge not processed at the conscious level; hence we can run fast over uneven ground without having to think or reflect on our activity. Our sense of up rightedness, of the effect of gravity on our physical movements, are as it were “built in” at a subconscious level enabling to move gracefully at various speeds. We occasionally make a mistake, but learning and memory mean we can deal with most contingencies, though occasional errors occur. We humans learn to contend with the illusions and vissitudes of life. They are simply part of the world we live in. Mostly we make our way through the world relatively safely, situations do occur that trick us and we either catch ourselves in time and avoid a mishap, or we misread the situation and pay the consequences.

King Pariksit says: In this material world there are as many living entities as atoms. Among these living entities, a very few are human beings, and among them, few are interested in following religious principles. O best of the brahmanas, Sukadeva Gosvami, out of many persons who follow religious principles, only a few desire liberation from the material world. Among many thousands who desire liberation, one may actually achieve liberation, giving up material attachment to society, friendship, love, country, home, wife and children. And among many thousands of such liberated persons, one who can understand the true meaning of liberation is very rare. O great sage, among many millions who are liberated and perfect in knowledge of liberation, one may be a devotee of Lord Narayana, or Krsna. Such devotees, who are fully peaceful, are extremely rare.—Srimad Bhagavatam 6.14.3-5

Sense alone cannot. Sense + some theories can help to discover errors and illusion, but it can never bring any certainty that we are in front of a reality, except the reality of our consciousness. Ancient philosophy argues (rather convincingly) in that direction, notably through the Dream Argument. The mechanist hypothesis in cognitive science + computer science (mathematical logic, arithmetic) proves this. Of course (?), we can’t *prove* the Mechanist hypothesis, but there too, we might be able to refute it. For example, if the laws of Newton were the correct fundamental laws of physics, Mechanism would be refuted. But with quantum mechanics, we might get confirmations of the most weird aspect of the Mechanist theory, where eventually the physical reality is shown to emerge from relation between the partial computable number relation and the non computable. With Mechanism, the illusions are the “real” things, and they obey precise mathematical laws allowing testing.

No, they can’t, but we have other means, like a brain for instance, and a capacity of abstract thinking or logical thinking. Besides, no matter how delusive our senses may be, it’s still not the instruments but our brain that can figure out an illusion. If you’re watching a fata morgana (a mirage) through binoculars, these will not tell you that it is a fata morgana. But your brain will. Besides, why does it matter if what you see is not real, if it helps you overcome an obstacle? For instance, you’re in danger, and you see “someone” scaring the attackers away. Later you figure out that what you saw was just an illusion. But what difference does it make whether it was real or not, given the fact that your problem was solved? The lesson that we are supposed to learn in a situation like that is not to argue over the reality of your vision, but to just become aware of the fact that there is always a solution to every problem, be the solution explainable or not.

It is not the senses that cannot be trusted, but the brain itself. As far as the brain is concerned, everything is an illusion — one that it itself has created. The sense organs only report what they sense (and in a very inadequate way). It is the brain that interprets them and formulates a model of the objective reality. But the sense organs being inadequate, the model is far from perfect. Hence, the illusion.

In general, yes, though it is obviously possible for the senses to be fooled. The problem is that the only thing we have to tell us when our senses are being fooled is our other senses. Incongruency between information coming from one sense and information coming from other senses is our prime indicator that something isn’t functioning correctly.

When the mind is spontaneous and silent, senses are perceived in choiceless thoughts. In such a case, the reality is perceived, as it is, the way it is, unchanging in the eternal now - like the sky or a mountain. However, when the mind is active - the reality is perceived by the senses to the extent it is observable and comprehensible to any individual. It continuously changes and is different from one to another. It becomes illusory - what seems to be real, is not. Meaning, the senses cannot be trusted, because of the mind by nature is restless, while it is awake and alive.
